metadata.title: A free-standing 3D nano-composite photo-electrode—Ag/ZnO nanorods arrays on Ni foam effectively degrade berberine

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Chemical Engineering Journal
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/cej
A free-standing 3D nano-composite photo-electrode—Ag/ZnO nanorods arrays on Ni foam effectively degrade berberine Yizhen Zhanga,b, Lifen Liua,c,⁎, Bart Van der Bruggend,e, Michael K.H. Leungb, Fenglin Yanga a Key Laboratory of Industrial Ecology and Environmental Engineering (MOE), School of Food and Environment, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China bAbility R&D Research Centre, School of Energy and Environment, City University of Hong, Hong Kong, China c School of Food and Environment, Dalian University of Technology, Panjin, China dDepartment of Chemical Engineering, KU Leuven, Celestijinenlaan 200F, Leuven, Belgium e Faculty of Engineering and the Built Environment, Tshwane University of Technology, Private Bag X680, Pretoria 0001, South Africa
H I G H L I G H T S
• A 3D free-standing photo-catalyst Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF was successfully prepared. • The enhanced photo-catalytic performance for degradation of berberine was obtained. • The photo-degradation intermediates of berberine and mechanisms were proposed. • The Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF photoanode was applied in PFC with effective performance.
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: ZnO nanorods arrays Ni foam Ag nanoparticles Photocatalysis Berberine
A B S T R A C T
Berberine is a widely used antibiotic in China, its photocatalytic degradation is not well understood nor its efficient treatment reported. In this study, it is most quickly and efficiently degraded (97.9% under UV and 98.9% under visible light) using a free-standing 3D composite photo-electrode, with well dispersed Ag nanoparticles (Ag NPs) over well-aligned ZnO nanorods arrays (ZnO NAs) on Ni foam (NiF), compared to ZnO NAs/ NiF, ZnO powder and P25. The composite photo-electrode was prepared by first directly growing ZnO NAs on NiF hydrothermally, followed by photo-deposition of Ag NPs, without any inactive binders or non-conductive substrates. It was characterized using scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray Diffraction (XRD), ultraviolet–visible spectrophotometry (UV–Vis) and electrochemical analysis (I-t, EIS). The highest activity of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF in degrading the target pollutant, is due to the synergy of easy pollutants diffusion and fast reaction on active sites, from suppressed electron-hole recombination by Ag NPs/ ZnO NAs heterojunctions, extended light absorption by surface plasmon resonance (SPR) of Ag NPs and accelerated electron transport on the conductive macro-porous NiF. The reactive oxidizing species (%OH, %O2−, h±), degradation intermediates and possible degradation pathways of berberine over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF were examined respectively. This free-standing whole piece photo-electrode with UV–visible light response, is easy to recycle and assemble, that not only degrades pollutant, but also generates electricity as photo-anode in a photo-catalytic fuel cell reactor using carbon fiber cloth as cathode.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cej.2019.05.026 Received 15 October 2018; Received in revised form 1 January 2019; Accepted 6 May 2019
⁎ Corresponding author at: Key Laboratory of Industrial Ecology and Environmental Engineering (MOE), School of Food and Environment, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China.
E-mail address: lifenliu@dlut.edu.cn (L. Liu).
Chemical Engineering Journal 373 (2019) 179–191
Available online 07 May 2019 1385-8947/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rapid population growth, along with social and economic development with industrialization and urbanization, lead to worldwide water pollution. Concerns about the resistance of widespread antibiotics, the pharmaceutical water pollution problem is significant, due to the profound potential risks and adverse impacts on the ecosystem and on human health [1,2]. The microbial community structure can be alter by antibiotics, because the antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) may persist in the environment and disseminate widely by a horizontal gene transfer mechanism in the environment [3,4]. It is hard to find an area where antibiotics cannot be detected in the surface water even in groundwater [5]. Therefore, finding solutions to tackle pharmaceutical pollution is urgent. Berberine is a widely used antibiotic in China; its degradation is not well understood nor efficiently carried out. Ren et al. reported that berberine hydrochloride wastewater can be treated by using pulse electro-coagulation with a Fe electrode, with 90.1% berberine hydrochloride and 62.6% COD removal [1]. Thus, the development of a method with higher activity and efficiency and lower energy cost is necessary.
As one of the advanced oxidation processes [6–10], photocatalysis can decompose and mineralize organic pollutants to CO2 and H2O [11–14,15]. Powder form photo-catalysts with high specific surface area often have excellent activities [16]. However, the powder catalyst easily aggregates. Filtration and separation is necessary for recovery and reuse [17,18]. To overcome these drawbacks, preparing high activity photo-catalyst on active substrates is desirable, with an ordered geometry and without using any binders [19–22]. Recently, efficient photocatalytic electrodes based on conductive substrates have been developed [23], for the readily applicable use in photo-catalysis and photo-electro-catalysis.
Photo-electro-catalyst ZnO (n-type, band gap ∼3.2 eV) has a high photosensitivity, thermal and photochemical stability, is easy to prepare and environmental-friendly [12,24–29]. Its properties are influenced by structure, shape/size and defect concentration. Among ZnO nanorods [24], tubes [30], wires [31], hexagonal disks and rings [32], and flowers [33,34], ordered nanorods ZnO array have a high surface area, efficient charge transport and excellent photoelectric performance [35]. It can grow on macro-porous three-dimensional (3D) Ni foam (NiF), forming a catalytic electrode with high electric conductivity and good mechanical stability [36]. Its composite with graphene has been used in photo-sensing [37], electronics and water splitting [38,39]. Au/ ZnO/graphene foam [40] and Cl-doped ZnO nanowire arrays/3D graphene foam have been prepared by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [41,42,43] or hydrothermal reduction of graphene oxides, after removal of a NiF template (that released Ni ions as secondary pollutants) [40,44]. The photo-catalytic performance of ZnO nanorods with NiF should be explored. ZnO heterojunctions with TiO2, NiO, SnO2 [45–48] and/or Ag, Au, Pt [25,40,49], further improve the photocatalytic
performance. What’s more, relative low-cost Ag also improves the photocatalytic properties in quantum efficiency, light scattering and surface plasmon resonance [35,50]. It is envisaged that Ag nanoparticles/ZnO nanorods arrays/Ni foam (denoted as Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/ NiF) would have better photocatalytic activity.
Here, the highly efficient 3D free-standing photo-catalysts were prepared with well dispersed Ag NPs bound to well-aligned ZnO nanorod arrays (directly grown on NiF, with ordered structure), without agglomeration (Scheme 1). This whole piece free-standing Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF can degrade berberine, a pharmaceutical pollutant, with high efficiency and stability. Furthermore, the mechanisms and degradations intermediate of photocatalytic performance enhancement over Ag NPs/ ZnO NAs/NiF were discussed in detail, using results from electron paramagnetic spinning resonance spectrometry (EPR) and high-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis (HPLCMS). The application of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF electrode in single chambered photo-catalytic fuel cell (PFC) with high performance was investigated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and materials
sections.text: Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn (NO3)2·6H2O), hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA), zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn (CH3COO)2·2H2O), silver nitrate, berberine chloride, and 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation (Shanghai, China). Other reagents, including absolute ethanol (C2H6O), acetone, isopropyl alcohol (IPA), ammonium oxalate (AO) and methyl orange (MO) were obtained from Damao Chemical Reagent Company (Tianjin, China). Deionized (DI) water was used in all experiments. All of these chemical reagents were analytical grade, without further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2. Photo-catalysts preparations (Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, ZnO NAs/NiF, and ZnO powder)
sections.text:
Nickel foam (NiF, 3.5 cm×6 cm) was used as the template and sequentially washed by acetone, ethanol and DI water for 10min each in ultrasound, and dried under vacuum before use. Combined seed layer and hydrothermal method were used to form vertical ZnO NAs on the surface of NiF. Initially, the ZnO nanocrystal layer was prepared on NiF to grow ZnO NAs. Briefly, a few drops of the obtained ZnO seed solution (0.01M Zn (CH3COO)2·2H2O in methanol) were added onto the NiF and dried in infrared rapid desiccator with 4 times repetition, followed by annealing at 200 °C to form a seed layer of ZnO nano-crystals. Subsequently, the above NiF was placed into a 100ml autoclave with ZnO seed layer side facing down, which was then filled with 70ml mixed solution containing 0.1M zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn
Scheme 1. Schematic illustration of the fabrication process of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF photo-catalyst.
(NO3)2·6H2O) and 0.1M hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA), at 95 °C for 6 h in a regular laboratory oven [43]. Finally, the ZnO NAs/NiF was obtained and rinsed with DI water then dried at room temperature. For comparison, ZnO powder was precipitated from the solution, collected and washed via centrifugation several times, followed by drying at 60 °C for 6 h. The Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF were prepared by immersing the ZnO NAs/NiF in 100ml silver nitrate ethylene glycol solution (AgNO3), subsequent adsorption with stirring in dark about 30min. The Ag NPs on the ZnO NAs/NiF surfaces were deposited by irradiation with 20W UV light for 20min, which reduced Ag ± to Ag NPs in AgNO3 solution. The final Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF was obtained after annealing at 350 °C for 1 h in air. In addition, a free-standing hybrid photo-catalyst ZnO nanorods arrays over carbon nanofiber cloth (denoted as ZnO NAs/CNC) was also prepared using similar seed layer and hydrothermal method.
Through changing the concentration of Zn (NO3)2·6H2O and HMTA, and AgNO3, series of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF photo-catalysts were fabricated. They were denoted as X-Ag NPs/Y-ZnO NAs/NiF, where “X” and “Y” represented the concentration (mM) of AgNO3 (X=0.25, 0.50, 1.00) and the same concentration (M) of Zn (NO3)2·6H2O and HMTA in mixed solution (Y= 0.05,0.10,0.15), respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3. Physicochemical characterization
sections.text: The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Empyrean) measurement of the samples was recorded using Co Kα (35 kV, 50mA) radiation at the working voltage of 35 kV and current of 50mA as the X-ray source, at a scanning rate of 5°/min in the range of 10° to 90°. Surface morphology and elemental analysis were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscope (NOVA NANOSEM 450, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was conducted to examine chemical compositions and the valence states of constituent elements in the catalysts on VG ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with Al Kα X-ray as the excitation source (1486.6 eV). Furthermore, the diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) was measured using an ultraviolet–visible spectrophotometer (JASCO Corp., V-550) to assess the light absorption range of catalysts.

sections.heading: 2.4. Photo-electrochemical characterization
sections.text: All photo-electrochemical measurements were carried out in an electrochemical workstation (CHI600E, Shanghai) with a 100ml three electrode test system, consisting of a working electrode, counter electrode (platinum sheet), and reference electrode (saturated calomel electrode, SCE). The pretreated Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, ZnO NAs/NiF, and NiF were employed as the working electrode for electrochemical characterization, respectively. The photocurrent responses of the sample were determined by amperometric I–t curve measurement with a bias voltage of 0 V (the open-circuit voltage of the samples) for 400 s in 0.2 mol/L Na2SO4 electrolyte. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of synthesized materials was measured in 0.2mol/L Na2SO4 electrolyte, at an open circuit potential over the frequency range of 0.1–100 kHz with or without light.

sections.heading: 2.5. Photocatalytic performance evaluation
sections.text:
The catalytic performance of as-synthesized foams was evaluated by the degradation of MO and berberine with an initial concentration of 10mg/L. UV light (20W) and a Xenon lamp (300W) were used as light source and the reaction in a quartz reactor was maintained at room temperature. The weight of the photo-catalysts on NiF was controlled at about 50mg and adjusted to be 0.5mg/mL (catalyst/solution) in all the degradation experiments. Prior to illumination, the mixture solution was placed in the dark and stirred for 30min to attain adsorption equilibrium on the surface of the corresponding catalyst.
During the photocatalytic degradation process, 1 ml of mixture
solution was taken out for a given time interval, subsequently diluted with DI water. The removal of MO and berberine during the degradation process was determined using a 752 UV–Vis spectrophotometer (Shanghai Jinghua Technology Instrument Corp., China). The absorbance spectra of MO and berberine chloride were measured at the same time interval, with the characteristic absorption peak of MO at 464 nm, and berberine chloride at 343 nm, to monitor the photocatalytic degradation process.
An electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer (EPR, Bruker Elexsys A200, Germany) was used to characterize the ROS generated using 50mmol/L DMPO as the spin trap reagent. In order to determine the degree of mineralization of berberine, total organic carbon (TOC) removal was determined using a total carbon analyzer (Shimadzu TOCVCPH, Japan). Furthermore, intermediates and products of berberine were determined by high performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry analysis (HPLC-MS, Thermo Finnigan, USA), equipped with a C18 column (2.1× 100mm, 3.5 µm). The mobile phase was composed of (A) water (containing 10mM ammonium formate and 0.1% formic acid), and (B) acetonitrile.

sections.heading: 2.6. Berberine degradation in a photocatalytic fuel cell
sections.text: This Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF photo-electrode was used as anode irradiated under 300W Xe lamp in a photocatalytic fuel cell comprising a carbon fiber cloth as cathode, with an external resistance of 2000 Ω. The reactor is made of quartz glass with 100ml volume. The concentration of 10mg/L berberine was used as the solution without any electrolyte (100ml). The cell voltage of this photocatalytic fuel cell was measured using a data collection system.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF
sections.text:
According to SEM images presented in Fig. 1 (a-g), an inter-penetrating macro-porous structure is seen for NiF, NiF with ZnO seed-layer and Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF. The macro-porous structure of NiF is unaltered nor clogged during modification with ZnO seed layer, growth of ZnO NAs and Ag NPs deposition (Fig. 1(a–c)). This structure facilitates diffusion and reaction of the target pollutant molecules not only on the outer surface of the foam but also on the interior surface [44]. After seeding layer modification (Fig. 1b), the representative SEM image of NiF has a stable and fixed ZnO layer, comparing with smooth surface of NiF (Fig. 1(a and d)). Fig. 1e–g, reveales well-aligned ZnO NAs on the NiF surface, with an average length of 1–2 μm and diameters of 200–300 nm. This is good for adsorbing target molecular and light harvesting. The surface of ZnO NAs, are decorated with deposited Ag NPs at diameter of ∼100 nm (Fig. 1g and S1). Furthermore, the prepared 3D free-standing Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF has stable structure and mechanical flexibility as shown in Fig. 1h. The associated energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental mappings verify that Zn, O, Ni and Ag are present in the composite Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF (Fig. 1i). Thus, the free-standing Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF has featured nanoarrays structure, is quite suitable for efficient photocatalytic application.
The composition of as-prepared foams was confirmed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) as displayed in Fig. 2. The high intensity peaks at 52.17°and 61.01° observed in Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, ZnO NAs/NiF and NiF, are assigned to the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni substrate. The diffraction XRD peaks at 37.06°, 40.19°, 42.35°, 55.81°, 66.80°, 74.53°, 78.94°, 80.93°, 82.38°and 86.80° corresponding to the (1 0 0), (0 0 2), (1 0 1), (1 0 2), (1 1 0), (1 0 3), (2 0 0), (1 1 2), (2 0 1) and (0 0 4), are consistent with the reference peaks from hexagonal wurtzite ZnO (JCPDS-36-1451) [51]. This confirms the successful growth of ZnO on the surface of NiF after the hydrothermal process. The characteristic diffraction peaks of Ag NPs at 44.56°, 51.90 °and 76.48° corresponding to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) are less obvious, due to the low
deposition weight and the overlap with the strong diffraction peak of foam nickel substrate.
The surface composition and chemical interaction of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF were characterized by X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS). In Fig. S2, the full spectra indicate that only Ni, O, Zn, and Ag elements exist in Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, while no other impurity elements are observed. The corresponding XPS spectra of the Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF: Zn 2p, Ag 3d, Ni 2p, and O 1 s, are shown in Fig. 3.
The peak centered at 1021.5 eV is assigned to the Zn 2p3/2, and another one centered at 1044.6 eV is correspond to Zn 2p1/2, implying a normal state of Zn2+ in the Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, as shown in Zn 2p spectra [31,52]. The Ag 3d spectrum of the Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF exhibits two peaks located at 367.8 and 373.8 eV, which are corresponding to the binding energies of Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2, respectively. The characteristic peaks corresponding to metallic Ni (852.3 and 870.9 eV) and Ni3+ (855.6 and 876.4 eV) can be observed [53]. The Ni 2p spectra show binding energy values at 873.0 and 879.9 eV, that are assigned to Ni 2p3/2 peak and its shakeup satellite peak, respectively, while 853.6 and 860.7 eV assigned to Ni 2p1/2 peak and its satellite peak, respectively, which are in accordance with Ni2+ characteristics [22]. The O 1s spectra shows asymmetric characteristic peaks at 528.9 eV, 530.4 eV, and 531.8 eV, confirming the formation of NiO, ZnO and Ni2O3, respectively [54]. However, due to low content and the overlap of the strong diffraction peak of nickel foam, no peaks for NiO and Ni2O3 can be observed in XRD, indicating that NiO and Ni2O3 are mostly on the surface of NiF.
In Fig. 4, the UV–Vis spectra of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, ZnO NAs/ NiF, NiF, P25 and ZnO powder are shown. The absorption edge of ZnO powder is about 380 nm, which is in accordance with its band gap. ZnO NAs/NiF has the similar absorption edge with ZnO powder. However, ZnO NAs/NiF has significantly increased absorption in both ultraviolet and visible-light region, compared with free ZnO powder without NiF, because of the unique the ZnO NAs structure on NiF. With deposition of Ag NPs, the ternary composite Ag NPs/ZnO NAs /NiF displays the highest absorption in both ultraviolet and visible-light region. The high absorbance of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF in visible light region can be
attributed to the surface plasmon resonance of Ag NPs. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and transient photocurrent response were measured to investigate the performances of charge generation, transfer and separation in the Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, ZnO NAs/NiF, and NiF. The electron-transfer resistance (Rct) values can be analyzed in the high frequency region of Nyquist plots in EIS measurements and is equivalent to the semicircle diameter. The Rct order is Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF with UV < Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF without UV < ZnO NAs/NiF with UV < ZnO NAs/NiF without UV (Fig. 5a). The Rct on the EIS Nyquist plots of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF is smaller than that of ZnO NAs/NiF both in the dark and under UV irradiation condition, demonstrating that the deposition of Ag NPs can reduce the transfer resistance of photo-generate carriers and consequently accelerate the interfacial charge transfer. It represents favorable effect of the Ag NPs on the prepared foams.
The I-t curves of these foam electrodes were tested when the potential was set at 0 V (vs. Hg/HgCl2) with alternating light on/off cycles (Fig. 5b). Upon UV irradiation, ZnO NAs/NiF, and Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/ NiF show pronounced and reproducible photocurrent responses, indicating the efficient charge separation in the composite materials with ZnO NAs [55]. Due to the smaller resistance after deposition of Ag NPs, the swift and stable photocurrent over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF is generated (2.5mA/cm2), while the photocurrent generation over NiF is around 0mA/cm2. After 400 s, the photocurrent density over Ag NPs/ ZnO NAs/NiF only slightly decreased from ∼2.5mA/cm2 to ∼2.4mA/ cm2, thus the stability of composite materials is proved. Its effective photoelectronic conversion properties are attributed to simultaneous promotion of light harvesting and photo-generated charge carriers separation. These properties will be beneficial for photocatalytic and photo-electrochemical reactions.

sections.heading: 3.2. Photo-catalyst optimized in preparation and degradation activities
sections.text:
The photo-catalytic performance of the as-prepared foams was evaluated by the degradation of MO (10mg/L) under UV light. Before illumination, all foams exhibit extremely weak adsorption of MO. To
optimize preparation condition, ZnO NAs/NiF and Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/ NiF were evaluated (Fig. S3). The obtained optimum preparation conditions are 95 °C, 0.1M, 6H for hydrothermal process and 0.25mM for Ag deposition for Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF. In Fig. 6a, commercial TiO2 (P25) has very low activity, the ZnO powder removes 58% MO after 120min UV irradiation. ZnO NAs/NiF has remarkably enhanced photocatalytic activity (～90% MO in 60min), Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF has the highest activity (99% MO removal in 60min), because the accelerated interfacial charge transfer with Ag NPs. In Fig. 6b, time-dependent UV−Vis absorption spectra are shown for the photo-catalytic degradation of MO over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF. The intensity of absorbency peak (MO at ∼464 nm), steadily decreases with irradiation time, to zero after 60min irradiation, meaning MO being degraded gradually.
For kinetic analysis, the MO photo-degradation reaction rates were calculated using a pseudo-first-order equation:
C C ktln ( / )t 0 =
where C0 is the initial concentration of the MO solution, Ct is the concentration of the MO at time t, and k is the apparent reaction rate constant. As shown in Fig. 6c, under UV light irradiation, the linear fitting of the experimental data for photocatalytic degradation of MO match well with the pseudo-first-order model. The rate constants of the Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, ZnO NAs/NiF, ZnO powder, ZnO NAs/CNC, NiF, P25 are 0.075, 0.049, 0.009, 0.0007, 0.001 and 0.003min−1, respectively. The quantitative analysis shows that the photocatalytic activity of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF is ∼25 times higher than that of P25, implying an obviously enhanced photocatalytic performance.
Several reactive species such as hydroxyl radicals (%OH), superoxide radicals (%O2−) and photo-generated holes (h± ) could participate in photocatalytic reactions. To study the contribution of active species in photocatalytic degradation over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, trapping experiments in the presence of different scavengers were conducted (60min UV irradiation) (Fig. 7). The MO removal was 99% after 60min UV irradiation over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF. With isopropanol (1mM) scavenging %OH, the MO removal (50.6%) was much lower, indicating that %OH radicals are the dominated active species. What’s more, adding %O2− scavenger (nitrogen) and h ± scavenger (ammonium oxalate, 1 mM), the degradation of MO is slightly suppressed, only reduced by 24% and 21%, respectively. It means that the %O2−, h+ and %OH radicals all participate in the photocatalytic degradation over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF under UV irradiation.
The stability and practicability are also important for commercial application in removal of contaminants. Four consecutive repeat tests for ZnO NAs/NiF and Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF indicated only slight decreasing in photocatalysis (Fig. 8a and b). Therefore, the as-synthesized composite catalyst can be a good candidate in practical wastewater treatments.

sections.heading: 3.3. Application for photodecomposition of berberine
sections.text:
Berberine is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, and an extensively used medicine. However, it is difficult to be degraded in wastewater, owing to its special chemical structures and bio-toxicity [1]. Consequently, its effective treatment demands continued effort. The as-synthesized photo-catalysts were tested to degrade berberine under UV and visible light illumination.
In Fig. 9a, Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF exhibits the best performance,
degrading ∼97.9% of berberine within 120min under UV light. The kinetic constants of the Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, ZnO NAs/NiF, ZnO powder, ZnO NAs/CNC, NiF, and P25 are estimated to be 0.0350, 0.0151, 0.0005, 0.0013, 0.0014 and 0.0011min−1, respectively (Fig. 9b). Under visible light, Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF photo-catalytically removed 98.9% berberine in 60min (Fig. 9c). As shown in Fig. 9d, the kinetic constant of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF is calculated to be 0.0776min−1, which was 1.14, 70.5, 32.3, 97, and 86.2 times those of ZnO NAs/NiF (0.0678min−1), ZnO powder (0.0011min−1), ZnO NAs/ CNC (0.0024min−1), NiF (0.0008min−1) and P25 (0.0009min−1). Fig. 9e-f displays the time-dependent UV−vis spectra for photocatalytic degradation of berberine in the presence of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF under irradiation. Obviously, the characteristic absorption peak of berberine decreases with the prolonged irradiation, suggesting valid decomposition under UV and Xenon lamp irradiation respectively. The decrease of TOC during berberine degradation over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF is shown in Fig. 9g, ～90% of berberine is completely mineralized after UV irradiation for 120min, indicating that low intermediates and by-products are formed during photocatalysis.
The intermediates of berberine during photo-degradation reaction were detected using HPLC-MS. The characteristic peak intensity of berberine (m/z 336.12) decreases with irradiation time (Fig. S4). The peaks at m/z 338.13, 193.12 and 165.01, is correspond to formed intermediates as shown in Fig. 10 and Fig. S5 [7]. According to the m/z values, it can be speculated that the pyridine ring in berberine molecules is firstly attacked by the main reactive species. Subsequently, intermediate products are generated by open-ring reaction with acidization and hydrogenation, forming low-molecular-weight intermediate products. Finally, certain intermediate products are further converted into CO2 and H2O via hydroxyl attack, in accordance with TOC analysis [7]. The possible photocatalytic degradation pathways and mineralization for berberine are proposed in Fig. 10.
Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF prepared in this study displays significantly high performances, attributed to the synergy of easy pollutants diffusion and fast reaction to active sites, from the suppressed electron-hole recombination by Ag NPs/ZnO NAs heterojunctions, the extended light absorption by SPR of Ag NPs and increased electron transport on the conductive NiF. Its photocatalytic degradation performance is compared with recent photocatalysis reports listed in Table 1.

sections.heading: 4. Reactive species and photocatalysis mechanism over Ag NPs/ ZnO NAs/NiF
sections.text:
To identify radical species, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spin trap technique was used in detecting the short-living radical species. To detect %OH, 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) dissolved in DI water (50mM) was used to measure the signals of DMPO/% OH species. The EPR four-line spectra signals (relative intensity of 1:2:2:1), represent the generated DMPO/%OH species. In Fig. 11a, under UV irradiation, the intensity of the characteristic 1:2:2:1 spectral peak for Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF is much stronger than ZnO NAs/NiF, indicating that %OH radicals produced on Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF are more than that on ZnO NAs/NiF. In contrast, no significant EPR signals were detected over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF in dark reactions and NiF during irradiation. What’s more, DMPO dissolved in absolute methanol was adopted as the spin-trapping agent to detect %O2−. In Fig. 11b, under UV light over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF, DMPO/%O2− species are detected, indicating that %O2− also contribute to photocatalytic degradation.
On the basis of the aforementioned analysis, a possible synergistic mechanism of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF for degradation MO and berberine is proposed in Scheme 2. There could be two possible mechanisms over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF under UV–visible light irradiation for the improvement in photocatalytic performance. The first possibility is under UV light that the photo-induced electrons in the valance band (VB) of ZnO NAs get excited to the conduction band (CB) leaving behind the holes, followed by transfer to inter-bands of Ag NPs and surface of NiF [67]. These electrons subsequently react with the surrounding O2 and produce %O2−, which further form H2O2 or %OH. The accumulated photo induced holes of ZnO NAs can directly oxidize the adsorbed H2O molecules to %OH, because the VB potential of ZnO NAs (+2.70 Ev vs. NHE) is more positive than the standard redox potential of %OH/OH− (+1.99 eV vs. NHE) [33,68,69,70]. The other possible mechanism is as follows. The Ag NPs strongly absorbs visible light via surface plasmon resonance (SPR), resulting in injection of the photo-induced electrons to the CB of ZnO NAs [71,72]. According to the band structures of Ag NPs/ ZnO NAs/NiF, the photo-induced electrons in the CB of ZnO NAs reduce the O2 in the solution to %O2− (−0.33 eV vs. NHE), ascribed to the more negative CB (−0.50 eV vs. NHE) of ZnO NAs [45]. %O2− may
(caption on next page)
further form H2O2 or %OH when protons exist [60]. Simultaneously, the photo induced holes can directly oxidize the H2O molecules to %OH, with suppressed electron-hole recombination.
All radical species (%OH, %O2−, h± ) participate in degrading MO and berberine over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF. The photo induced electrons partially transfer from photocatalyst surface to high conductive NiF surface, accelerated the electrons transfer process to suppress electronhole recombination. The high activity of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF is attributed to its unique structures, extended visible light absorption, enhanced transfer and separation of photo generated electron-holes, with
efficient generation of plenty reactive radicals to participate the photocatalytic process.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion about its use as photo-anode in PFC
sections.text:
A photo-catalytic fuel cell (PFC) is an attractive developed technology, promising for simultaneous wastewater treatment and electricity generation, in spite of the insignificant power generation [73]. The photo-electrons are transferred from anode to cathode by selfgenerated bias rather than additional applied voltage, which reduce the
Fig. 9. The photodegradation activities of berberine as a function of time over different photo-catalysts under UV irradiation (a) and Xenon lamp (c), reaction kinetics of berberine over different prepared photo-catalysts under UV irradiation (b) and Xenon lamp (d), time-dependent UV−vis spectra of berberine solution under UV irradiation (e) and Xenon lamp (f), and the TOC removal of berberine under UV irradiation for Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF with prolongation of irradiation time (g).
Fig 10. Analysis of degradation intermediates and possible degradation pathways of berberine (the structures are color-coded as follows: light grey: H, red: O, grey: C, blue: N, green: Cl). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)
overall energy consumption in PFC [74]. The prepared free-standing Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF has effective photocatalytic performance and stable mechanical properties. Thus, this Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF electrode was directly applied for degrading berberine in single chambered PFC and irradiated by Xenon lamp, with carbon fiber cloth as counter electrode.
As shown in Fig. 12 a, after 1 h of irradiation, 99.0% of the berberine (10mg/L) is degraded and ∼150mV cell voltage is generated when the external resistance is 2000 Ω in a single chambered PFC system, while only ∼50mV cell voltage is generated without light. Because more photo-electrons are produced by Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF anode under irradiation, and transfer from anode to cathode to create a cell voltage, with less combination of photo-holes and photo-electron.
In future studies, new PFC system with more effective counter electrode instead of carbon fiber cloth electrode could be constructed to match the Fermi levels of Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF (Fig. 12b). Photo-catalyst, electro-catalyst and photo/electro-catalyst can be investigated as counter electrode functional materials in PFC system. Being competitive in efficiency and energy-saving performances, this free-standing Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF photo-electrode will be tested in future in treating other types of pollutants, in examining electrode size and operation scales for application potential.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
A novel free-standing photo-catalyst Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF was successfully prepared with dispersed Ag NPs on well-aligned ZnO NAs, by directly grown on NiF hydrothermally. Compared with P25, ZnO powder and binary ZnO NAs, the ternary Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF exhibits the highest photocatalytic activity and great mineralization efficiency for degrading berberine. The hydroxyl radicals are the major species for degradation, the photo-induced superoxide radicals and photo-generated holes, also contribute to the degradation. The excellent pollutant degradation performance over this new photo-electrode can be attributed to the synergy of easy pollutants diffusion and fast reaction on active sites, from the suppressed electron-hole recombination by Ag NPs/ZnO NAs heterojunction, the increased light harvesting by SPR of Ag NPs and accelerated electron transport on the conductive macroporous NiF. The photocatalytic berberine degradation mechanism over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF was examined using HPLC-MS, that identified two main intermediates at m/z 193 and 165. This study not only provides method of preparing free-standing UV–visible photo electrode catalysts for treatment antibiotic wastewater, but also provides effective photocatalytic and photo-electrochemical fuel cell process for
Scheme 2. Schematic illustration of the proposed photo-degradation mechanism over Ag NPs/ZnO NAs/NiF under UV–visible light.
treating pollutions with competitive energy-saving and cost-saving performance.

The first possibility is under UV light that the photo-induced electrons in the valance band (VB) of ZnO NAs get excited to the conduction band (CB) leaving behind the holes, followed by transfer to inter-bands of Ag NPs and surface of NiF [67].
The Ag NPs strongly absorbs visible light via surface plasmon resonance (SPR), resulting in injection of the photo-induced electrons to the CB of ZnO NAs [71,72].

further form H2O2 or %OH when protons exist [60].

A photo-catalytic fuel cell (PFC) is an attractive developed technology, promising for simultaneous wastewater treatment and electricity generation, in spite of the insignificant power generation [73].
